description: Borrowed from Latin regulatus, past participle of regulō (“to direct, rule, regulate”), from regula (“rule”), from regō (“to keep straight, direct, govern, rule”). Compare regle, rail. Displaced native Old English metegian. Equivalent to regular +‎ -ate.

verbs.description: regulate (third-person singular simple present regulates, present participle regulating, simple past and past participle regulated)

entries.meaning: To control or direct according to rule, principle, or law.
examples: The herdsmen near the frontier adjudicated their own disputes, and regulated their own police.

entries.meaning: To adjust to a particular specification or requirement: regulate temperature.
To adjust (a mechanism) for accurate and proper functioning.
examples: to regulate a watch, i.e. adjust its rate of running so that it will keep approximately standard time
to regulate the temperature of a room, the pressure of steam, the speed of a machine, etc.

entries.meaning: To put or maintain in order.
examples: to regulate the disordered state of a nation or its finances
